docblock.description: A class for managing CRUD database functionality.
docblock.long-description:
* MODIFIED from standard to put a "created date" in automatically. All children must have a field nicknamed "created".
In your extension of this class, you should fill in the following:
$table_name $fields $field_nicks_map $searchable_nicks $sortable_nicks $editable_nicks
Assumption: The nickname 'id' will be used to represent the primary key. If this is not the case, you can set $constructor_key to the primary key nickname.

docblock.description: A class for managing CRUD database functionality.
docblock.long-description:
* MODIFIED from standard to put a "created date" in automatically. All children must have a field nicknamed "created".
In your extension of this class, you should fill in the following:
$table_name $fields $field_nicks_map $searchable_nicks $sortable_nicks $editable_nicks
Assumption: The nickname 'id' will be used to represent the primary key. If this is not the case, you can set $constructor_key to the primary key nickname.

docblock.description: The name of the table in the database. Use to construct queries
A mapping of nicknames to actual table names, like so: array( "id" => "p_id", "nickname" => "table_column_name" )
docblock.long-description: When constructing queries, use static::$field_nicks_map['nickname'] to represent your field names. This will give you a layer of indirection that will allow you to change your database field names without having to update all your queries.

docblock.description: A list of fields that can be searched. USE NICKNAMES.
docblock.long-description: Implementation note: All searchable nicks should be indexed.

docblock.description: A list of fields that can be sorted. USE NICKNAMES.
A list of fields that can be edited. USE NICKNAMES.
The nickname of the column used to construct a new instance.
docblock.long-description:
Usually this will be 'id'. You can customize it for different primary keys. For example, in things like user accounts tables, you may want to change this to 'username'
This should always be a unique column, if not the primary key

docblock.description: Load a database entry by its constructor key.
docblock.long-description:
Constructor key defaults to 'id', but can be changed in subclasses.
Additional options are for loading presearched data. Pass $load=false and $row=array to load a row from a record into this object

docblock.description: Create a new database entry
docblock.long-description:
MODIFIED from standard to put a created date in automatically. All children must have a field nicknamed "created".
Separated from __construct because of a data leak in the previous project that hinged on conditional creation of entries based on input to the function.
Accepts a hash of known values to put into the row, with keys as field nicknames and values as table values.
Assumption: An autoincrement primary key will have a nickname 'id'
Assumption: If the primary/constructor key is not autoincrement, you will have provided it in the $knowndata

docblock.description: Save the values in the object to the db.
docblock.long-description:
Will throw an error if it thinks that the object hasn't had all the attributes loaded and you try to save all fields. This will occur when creating the object and populating it with data from an externally retrieved record. Since the object didn't create the record, it doesn't trust that it has all the object's data in it. If it doesn't have all the data, then a save could overwrite valid data with an empty field.
The error is bypassed by specifying which fields you want to save. If you can specify the fields you want to save, then you've probably loaded them.

docblock.description: Destroy the record.
docblock.long-description:
Deletes the record from the database.
Override to create a soft-delete.

docblock.description: Set the value of a field, by nickname.
docblock.long-description:
Automatically saves the field to the db.
Can be set "softly" by setting the $save param to false. Data will be set in this object, but not saved in the db. You must then manually call $this->save() to save the data to the db.

tag.name: param
tag.description: if omitted, the value is saved to the database. if anything other than boolean true is passed, it will not save to the db.

docblock.description: Basic search for records
docblock.long-description:
This function allows two basic types of search: 1) The most generic search -> search all $searchable_nicks for a phrase that contains the search term. (field LIKE '%term%' OR field LIKE '%term%') 2) The most restrictive search -> search only the listed fields for the exact values provided. (field = term AND field = term)
All other implementations need to be written for each class. Please do not let your SQL queries creep out of the objects and into the controllers.
Returns an array of instantiated objects. **An empty result set will return an empty array.
-krs Should I write this? Or leave most of the searching to be written independently so the sql doesn't creep into the controller.

docblock.description: retrieve all rows from the table
Search only the listed fields for the exact values
Search any of the searchable fields for the search term.
A utility function to hold the frequently repeated code that happens when you write a simple query and need it processed to objects.
docblock.long-description: Since it is marking the objects as loaded, please make sure that your query is "SELECT *..." if you are using this to load the objects. Objects that are incorrectly marked as loaded can destroy data in the database when saved.

docblock.description: Process an individual search result row into an object
docblock.long-description: Left public because of scoping issues when passing functions around

docblock.description: Mark the objects as properly loaded.
docblock.long-description: Call this only when you have set all of the attributes on the object from the database.

docblock.description: Returns an array of the actual field names, given an array of the nicknames.

docblock.description: A class for conditionally printing output to the screen. The debug class allows you to leave important debug statements in the code while centrally deciding whether they will print their output or not.
docblock.long-description:
Output can also be buffered and then printed when desired.
All of the functions in Debug work only if the class has been activated by a call to DEBUG::activate();

docblock.description: Function Parameter Extension
docblock.long-description:
Allows you to explicitly declare contracts on parameters.
To save time, this can be deactivated in production so that the checks are skipped.

docblock.description: Create a contract for the parameters when they are passed to the function as an array.
docblock.long-description:
The contract is formatted as: array( 'required'=>array(array('required', 'group'), array('alternate', 'required', 'group'), 'optional'=>array('optional', 'params') ) where only one of the required groups must have all of its parameters satisfied. The optional list will restrict the parameters to only those listed in the contract, to help catch typos and let you know when you've used an invalid parameter.
A fun idiom: public static function inventoryDelivery($pArr){ extract(FPX::contract(array( "required" => array('start_date', 'end_date'), "optional" => array('rollup', 'report_format') ))); Now all your defined variables are ready for use, just as if you'd declared them normally. Use of extract() is ok because we define the params, and contract() is returning our defs.

docblock.description: These tests are a little tricky because DEBUG is never instantiated and only used as static. Because of that, each time we make a test, we have to pull the current values of things that we are going to change, and make sure to set them back to the values that existed before the test once we've run our test.
